item.title: How large is Greenland, really? Your map may be deceiving you
item.description: Talk of annexation has Greenland in the news again. But due to quirks of cartography, some common maps show the territory much larger than it is.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Sick young ants send out a 'kill me' scent to prevent deadly epidemics
item.description: Young, infected Lasius neglectus ants will send out an altruistic "kill me" signal to worker ants, a new study finds, as part of a strategy to keep deadly pathogens from spreading through the colony.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: 'Everything I knew burned down around me': A journalist looks back on LA's fires
item.description: Jacob Soboroff was raised in the Pacific Palisades and reported live from the area as it was devastated by fire in 2025. In Firestorm, Soboroff offers a minute-by-minute account of the catastrophe.

item.title: What 'Stranger Things' gets right about wormholes
item.description: The much anticipated series finale of Netflix's Stranger Things is predicated on wormholes — a concept in physics that often appears in science fiction. So what are wormholes?

item.title: A new analysis reveals clues about when primates started walking on two feet
item.description: A big difference between humans and other apes is the ability to stride easily on two feet. A new analysis of fossil bones shows that adaptations for bipedal walking go back 7 million years.

item.title: Brain organoids are helping researchers, but their use also creates unease
item.description: Pea-size clusters of human cells called brain organoids inspire both hope and fear. Experts are debating how scientists can responsibly use these bits of gray matter.

item.title: What Stranger Things gets right about wormholes
item.description: The final episode of fifth season of the Netflix series Stranger Things is out this week, and the concept of a wormhole figures largely into it. While the show is a work of fiction, theoretical wormholes have making appearances for decades not only in science fiction but in actual science.

item.title: Uncovering the mystery of how algae makes snow green, red or orange
item.description: Snow isn't always white; algae can make it look green, red, or orange, and scientists are trying to understand how and why these colorful patches appear.
